thread.title: New Oceania ship to offer South Pacific, Australia cruises
thread.title_full: New Oceania ship to offer South Pacific, Australia cruises

title: New Oceania ship to offer South Pacific, Australia cruises
text:
An artist's drawing of Oceania Cruises' next ship, Sirena. The line is taking over and revamping the 684-passenger vessel from Princess Cruises, where it currently sails as the Ocean Princess. Oceania Cruises Fullscreen Princess Cruises' 684-passenger Ocean Princess. Princess Cruises Fullscreen An artist's drawing of the new Italian eatery, Tuscan Steak, planned for Oceania Cruises' 684-passenger Sirena. Oceania Cruises Fullscreen An artist's drawing of the Asian eatery Red Ginger planned for Oceania Cruises' 684-passenger Sirena. Oceania Cruises Fullscreen The Red Ginger restaurant on Oceania's Sirena will be similar to eateries on the line's Marina and Riviera. Oceania Cruises Fullscreen The Tuscan Steak restaurant planned for Oceania's Sirena is a new concept for the line. Oceania Cruises Fullscreen Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay Autoplay Show Thumbnails Show Captions Last Slide Next Slide An artist's drawing of Oceania Cruises' next ship, Sirena. The line is taking over and revamping the 684-passenger vessel from Princess Cruises, where it currently sails as the Ocean Princess. (Photo: Oceania Cruises)
1 CONNECT 3 TWEET 4 LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE The new Oceania ship debuting in 2016 will spend its first winter sailing across the Pacific to Australia.
Oceania on Wednesday announced the 684-passenger Sirena would begin a journey westward from Miami in November 2016 with a 16-night voyage through the Panama Canal to Los Angeles.
After two sailings out of Los Angeles to Mexico in December 2016, the former Princess vessel will travel from Los Angeles to Tahiti in January and operate South Pacific cruises through early February before continuing on to Australia. The ship will sail around Australia and New Zealand for about two months before returning eastward to Tahiti and Los Angeles.
Currently sailing as the Ocean Princess, Sirena will join the Oceania fleet in April after a massive, $40 million makeover that will include a significant overhaul of its top decks, lounges and 342 cabins.
USA TODAY
First look: Oceania Cruises' soon-to-debut Sirena
With the addition, Oceania will have six vessels in its fleet.
Sirena is a sister to three ships already in the Oceania fleet -- Regatta, Insignia and Nautica -- and will offer a similar array of amenities including a fitness center and spa; six lounges and bars; and a casino. It's scheduled to enter service for Oceania on April 27, 2016 with a 14-night cruise from Barcelona to Venice.
Sirena also will share many of the features found on the line's newest vessel, Riviera. For a deck-by-deck tour of the ship, scroll through the carousel below.
Christened in Barcelona on May 11, 2012, the 1,250-passenger Riviera is upscale Oceania Cruises' second new ship in just over a year. What's it like on board the vessel? USA TODAY's Gene Sloan sailed on a preview voyage and offers a photo tour. Oceania Cruises Fullscreen Riviera's pool deck features a heated saltwater swimming pool, two freshwater whirlpools and plush lounge chairs. Gene Sloan Fullscreen A close-up view of one of the two hot tubs on Riviera's pool deck. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Lounge chairs around the ship's pool are covered in plush towels. Gene Sloan Fullscreen A shaded area called The Sanctuary, near the pool deck, offers a quiet retreat. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Another covered deck-top area for lounging is called The Patio. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Among the diversions on the top decks of the ship is an 18-hole putting green and a paddle tennis court. Gene Sloan Fullscreen A close-up of the paddle tennis court, which is located at the front of the vessel. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Riviera also has a golf driving cage, located adjacent to the ship's putting green. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The top deck of the ship also offers a shuffleboard area, located toward the back of the ship on what's known as the Sports Deck. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The Sports Deck also features a croquet court. Gene Sloan Fullscreen A small jogging track surrounds the Riviera's funnel. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Cuisine is a major focus aboard Riviera, which features 10 different dining venues. Among them: Toscana, an Italian eatery that's open for dinner by reservation. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The 538-seat Grand Dining Room is the main restaurant on the ship and serves Continental cuisine. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Privee, a posh private dining room overlooking the back of the ship, can be booked for dinner for a flat fee of $250. It seats up to 10 people. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Jacques, a 124-seat restaurant serving French cuisine, was created by noted French chef Jacques Pepin. It's his second restaurant at sea (the first is on Riviera's one-year-old sister ship, Marina). Gene Sloan Fullscreen Another eatery on Riviera is Polo Grill, a steakhouse that is a signature of Oceania vessels. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Oceania's Asian eatery, Red Ginger, is open nightly for dinner by reservation. Like other Oceania specialty restaurants, it is available to passengers at no extra charge. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The Terrace Caf√© is Riviera's casual buffet eatery, open for breakfast, lunch and dinner. It offers indoor and outdoor seating overlooking the back of the ship. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The outdoor seating area of the Terrace Cafe overlooks the back of the ship. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The food serving area of the Terrace Cafe. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Waves Grill, an open-air eatery near the pool, serves grilled items such as burgers, and has a salad bar. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The grill area at Waves Grill. Passengers place orders at the counter and the dishes then are delivered to tables by waiters. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Adjacent to Waves Grill is an ice cream outlet serving more than half a dozen flavors. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The 24-seat La Reserve by Wine Spectator dining room offers seven-course meals paired with fine wines for $95 per person. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Passengers can create an ice cream sundae at the ice cream outlet with a variety of toppings. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Marina has an elegant, boutique hotel-like feel with rich wood paneling and hand-picked art. Here, a stairwell featuring a glass art piece. Gene Sloan Fullscreen A seating area in the ship's main entryway. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Passengers enter the Riviera into an elegant two-deck-high space that contains the ship's reception and destination-services desks. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The reception area of the Marina features the Grand Staircase, a double stairway with crystal medallions commissioned from Lalique. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The base of the Grand Staircase has a Lalique signature Cactus Table surrounded by etched crystal screens and flanked by newels capped with prominent crystal finials. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The ship's reception desk. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The destination services desk, where passengers can make arrangements for shore excursions. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The Horizons observation lounge is located at the front top of the ship and offers sweeping views of the sea. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The Horizons lounge also features a dance floor and is a hotspot for nighttime entertainment on the ship. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Located on Deck 6, Martinis is a central gathering place for passengers in the evenings. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Martinis features live piano music nightly. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The Grand Bar, a long, narrow lounge area located adjacent to the Grand Dining Room, is another prime location for pre-dinner drinks. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The Riviera offers a small casino with a handful of table games and slot machines. Gene Sloan Fullscreen A row of slot machines in the Riviera's casino. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The Casino Bar, just off the ship's casino, has a modern vibe and a purple glow. Gene Sloan Fullscreen A sitting area in the Casino Bar. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Located at the top of the ship overlooking the pool area, Baristas is a small coffee bar serving Italian espressos and cappuccinos. Gene Sloan Fullscreen A close-up of the elegant Italian coffee maker used at Baristas. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The ship's cozy Library features rich, wood-paneled walls and bookcases, and leather seating. Gene Sloan Fullscreen A seating area in the ship's Library. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The standard balcony cabins on Riviera, known as Veranda Staterooms, are billed as the largest in the industry at 282 square feet. They feature a sitting area, large bathroom and teak-floored deck with faux-wicker furnishings. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Balconies in Veranda Staterooms have two chairs and a small table. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Balconies in Veranda Staterooms have two chairs and a small table. Gene Sloan Fullscreen At 420 square feet, Riviera's Penthouse Suites are about 50% larger than Veranda Staterooms with bigger bedrooms, bathrooms and balconies. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Penthouse Suites have long built-in cabinetry containing storage for clothing and a mini-bar. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The desk area of Penthouse Suites come with a laptop to use during the cruise. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Amenities in Penthouse Suites include Oceania Cruises' own brand of mineral water. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Balconies in Penthouse Suites have two chairs and a small side table. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Penthouse Suites and other cabins feature multiple outlets for U.S.-style plugs and separate outlets for European-style plugs. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Penthouse Suites have large walk-in closets that contain space for hanging clothes, built-in drawers and a safe. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Bathrooms in Penthouse Suites boast large sink areas, a separate shower and tub. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Showers in Penthouse Suites are larger than the ones in Veranda Staterooms. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Penthouse Suite bathrooms feature upscale Bulgari bath products. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Miniature refrigerators are a standard feature in all cabins on Riviera. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The safes found in Riviera cabins are large enough for wallets, passports and cameras but not a full-size laptop. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Among Riviera's largest accommodations are its eight Vista Suites, created by noted designer Dakota Jackson. Ranging in size from 1,200 to 1,500 square feet, they all are located at the front of the ship and offer sweeping views over the bow. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The master bathroom of a Vista Suite. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Vista Suites include a large living room separated from the bedroom. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Each of the ship's eight Vista Suites also include a personal workout room. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Like this topic?
